ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: so much - about power, language, methods, institutions, resistance, working within the academy

I developed expansive and in-depth knowledge on ethnic studies. We learned about the key, foundational texts in ethnic studies as well as praxis, poetry, prose, etc. I also developed my ability to discuss these texts in conversation with each other and comparatively. Furthermore, I developed my ability to write candidly about these readings and ethnic studies as a whole. Lastly, we learned a lot about ethnic studies methodologies.
It was great to engage with books/theory that are foundational to ethnic studies. I also learned a lot from my classmates/the ER&M cohort.

We read and learned the important themes in seminal works in ethnic studies. I gained an understanding the importance and role of ethnic studies in my life. I learned to appreciate different types of works such as poetry.
I learned so much about critical readings and teachings in ER&M, this was an intellectually challenging ER&M class and was wonderful to expand my horizons and reading base
Reading poetry, writing memos, engaging in some of the Poetry for the People pedagogy

This course is exactly what is needed at the mid-way point of ones education in ethnic studies and related areas. The class is a small seminar environment in which we can share and discuss each others writings, build community, and deepen our understanding of key concepts like the oppositional strain, coloniality and anticolonialism in language, encoding/decoding, carcerality and abolition, kinship and rupture, Saidiya Hartmans work of critical fabulation, gender liberation vs. ungendering, and colonial anthropology and contending with/rearranging the archive.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I liked the structure of the class, Monday lecture and Wednesday discussion.

strengths: structure of the class, Prof. Omar is so kind and warm, final project presentation was really cool!
weaknesses: lectures could be slow sometimes
This course was absolutely incredible. Everything about this course with Professor Omar is a strength! She crafted an exceptional syllabus and I couldnt have imagined a better ER&M 300 experience.

The strengths is that Professor Omar allowed students different ways to show their learningmemos, performances, final reflections. We were treated like more than studentshuman beings who are vulnerable, who make mistakes, who like to talk about heavy topics that affect all our lives. The community that I found in ER&M 300 was so accepting and kind. 

The one weakness is that discussion could be more guided or structured. It might be helpful to have students post discussion questions before class to ensure that everyone did the readings, read the memos, and have questions or comments to say before coming to class. Then, Professor Omar or a designated student leader could guide the discussion making it clear what theme we are discussing and keep track of the time.
The class focuses deeply on readings and topics which made it so nice to really delve into readings and analysis of them, I learned so much, it was organized wonderfully

Strengths: having conversations with everyone in the class
Weaknesses: I would have preferred to not share my work with all classmates and instead only with the professor

Prof. Omar is amazing and has introduced a helpful new course structure in which, every week, a few students write exploratory memos on the readings, and we then use these memos as a starting point for group discussions. This allows us to receive feedback and find connections between each others writings over time, so that each memo does not feel like a one-off assignment but something that we are continually learning from. At the end of the course, we all participated in a group performance at the Palestine Museum in Woodbridge and had the chance to hear directly from Faisal Saleh, who founded and runs the museum. This was a beautiful experience and I hope that future classes get to see the Palestine Museum too. And we all cannot say enough about Prof. Omar; she has so much knowledge to share, and also created an environment that encouraged us to participate in collective knowledge-sharing. Prof. Omar is an alum of June Jordans Poetry for the People program, and it is so exciting to feel some of these practices being passed along to us.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, the course readings generated great discussions this semester which kept me engaged every class.
yes for ER&M majors

I would 100% recommend this course to other students. ER&M students are required to take this course, but even if you are not an ER&M major, you should take this class. This class will teach you about the world, and about yourself, through a critical, yet necessary lens. I have nothing but good things to say about this course.
Yes I would recommend this course because you get to meet really cool people and read really cool work.

Absolutely! This is required for the ER&M major so I was fully prepared to just go through it but it ended up being one of my favorite ER&M classes, the readings were incredible, the discussions were the best I've ever had in a class, and Professor Omar was AMAZING
Yes! Very good course even if you are not an ER&M major

Yes, absolutely!! The course is required for ER&M majors but not a chore by any means  some of the most important texts you may ever read will be in this class, and it is a great chance to deepen connections with the people in and around your year in the major. Between everybody in the class, there will be a richness of experiences with different courses, theories, and forms of community work.
